review: I travel frequently and I purchased the Amazon Fire TV Stick to take along with me to have access to the streaming content I enjoy at home. The Amazon Fire TV Stick allows you to connect to hotel Wi-Fi, which often requires acceptance of term and/or authentication to connect. This is an advantage over the Roku Stick, which does not open a browser to connect to the Wi-Fi landing page. The hardware for the Amazon Fire TV Stick is also better than the Roku Stick.One big disadvantage for the Amazon Fire TV is the UI, which seems to be designed solely to sell you more Amazon services. See here for screenshots of the UI: http://www.engadget.com/gallery/amazon-fire-tv-ui-screenshots/ Missing from the screenshots is the banner advertisement on the Home page. In my opinion, the Home page would be better served offering a landing page for MY content, not redundant links to Amazon services already profusely offered on other menu pages.The search feature is inconsistent and does not always correctly identify that a searched item is available for free from another app (such as HBO Go or Netflix). Instead, the searched item is offered to purchase from Amazon. In comparing the search features between Fire TV and Roku, the Roku search correctly offered the free choice over paid services.Regarding miracast streaming from an external device to the Fire TV stick, all Windows devices are left out. So, if you are a Microsoft Surface owner you are better off with Roku devices that support it.Frankly, I'd return it, but it minimally suits my needs for streaming entertainment when I travel.
author: Christopher Shilt
